definition:
Let $F,G: \mathcal{C}\to \mathcal{D}$ be a pair of functors from the
category $\mathcal{C}$ to the category $\mathcal{D}$. A natural
transformation between functors $\tau : F\to G$ is called a [*natural
equivalence*]{} (or a [*natural isomorphism*]{}) if there is a natural
transformation $\sigma : G\to F$ such that
$\tau\bullet \sigma = {\rm id}_G$ and $\sigma\bullet \tau = {\rm id}_F$
where ${\rm id}_F$ is the identity natural transformation on $F$, and
composition $\bullet$ is the usual (vertical) composition on natural
transformations.

Equivalently, one can define a natural equivalence from functors $F$ to
$G$ to be a natural transformation $\tau$ such that for each object $A$
in $\mathcal{C}$, the morphism $\tau_A : F(A)\to G(A)$ is an isomorphism
in $\mathcal{D}$.
